title: 111_hr2667
content: The "Early Support for Families Act" establishes grants for quality home visitation programs for families with young children and expecting families under the Social Security Act. The purpose of this section is to improve the well-being of children by establishing quality home visitation programs for families with young children and expecting families. States seeking grants must submit an application describing the programs, intended outcomes, and evidence of effectiveness. The curr_chunk discusses the results of a needs assessment for home visitation programs for families with young children and expecting families in the state, including program quality, funding sources, gaps in services, and training activities. The curr_chunk outlines assurances from the State to prioritize serving high-need communities in home visitation programs, reserve 5% of grant funds for training, and promote coordination with other child services. The State must prioritize serving high-need communities in home visitation programs, reserve 5% of grant funds for training, and promote coordination with other child services. Additionally, home visitation programs should provide referrals to other programs serving children and families, comply with regulations, and cooperate with evaluations. The Secretary shall allot funds to Indian tribes and States based on the number of children in need, with priority given to high-need communities in home visitation programs. The Secretary allots funds to Indian tribes and States based on the number of children in need, with priority for high-need communities in home visitation programs. Reallotments of unspent funds are available for redistribution. States must maintain a certain level of expenditure to meet requirements from fiscal year 2011 onwards. The Secretary provides grants to States meeting specific requirements for home visitation programs, based on eligible expenditures and allotted amounts. The reimbursable percentage for fiscal years varies from 85% in 2010 to 75% in 2012 and beyond. Eligible expenditures include providing voluntary home visitation for families with young children through evidence-based programs. The home visitation program must adhere to evidence-based models, employ well-trained staff, and establish linkages to community resources. This includes expenditures for training and technical support. Priority funding is given to programs with the strongest evidence of effectiveness in home visitation. Expenditures for training, technical assistance, and evaluations related to the programs must adhere to evidence-based models to be considered eligible. The applicable percentage for fiscal years 2010 to 2014 is defined in subparagraph (A). States receiving grants under this section cannot use other federal funds for their share of costs. The Secretary has the authority to waive or modify provisions of this section. The Indian tribe can be exempt from certain provisions of this section if it would create an undue burden. States receiving grants must report annually on the progress of programs funded by the grant. The characteristics of programs funded by grants include service model, provider qualifications, recipient demographics, program costs, outcomes, and training provided for implementation. The evaluation of home visitation programs funded under this section includes examining their impact on child and parent outcomes, such as child maltreatment, health, development, and school readiness, as well as the effectiveness of these programs. The Secretary is required to submit interim and final reports to Congress within 2 and 4 years, respectively, on the evaluation of home visitation programs' effectiveness on different populations. Additionally, annual reports on program activities must be submitted to Congress. The report to Congress on activities funded under this section includes details on targeted high need communities, service delivery models, program characteristics, outcomes, and research-based materials. The report to Congress includes details on research-based instruction, materials, training activities, annual costs, and monitoring methods for programs funded under the grant. Additionally, $10,000,000 is reserved for evaluation, training, and technical assistance for early childhood home visitation programs. The Secretary is appropriated funds for early childhood home visitation programs, with specific amounts allocated for fiscal years 2010 to 2014. Additionally, grants are provided to Indian tribes under this section.
